32.20.text:
Alright, I'm talking
specifically about this scene

34.37.text: in Guardians of the Galaxy Volume 1,

36.27.text:
when Peter Quill
intentionally exits his ship

38.71.text: to gift Gamora his kick-ass mask.

It looks like he spends
a fair amount of time

42.99.text: in the vacuum of space without exploding

45.19.text:
or bleeding from the eyes like
we've seen in other films.

47.94.text:
So, which version of death
by space is accurate?

51.61.text: First of all, space is deadly.

53.59.text:
There's no air for you
to breathe in space,

59.57.text:
Humans, like every
other organism on Earth,

61.62.text: evolved under some kind of pressure,

63.63.text: pushing down on me, pushing down on you,

68.12.text:
For us primates, that
pressure has always been about

75.00.text:
or around 15 pounds per
square inch of pressure,

78.22.text:
and that comes from the mass
of air that surrounds us.

81.05.text: That pressure, in part, helped determine

83.01.text: what our bodies would look like,

84.64.text: how our blood would carry gas,

87.57.text:
and even how our lungs
would be able to force air

92.13.text:
So, if all the air was
suddenly sucked away from us,

112.33.text:
So, if all the air was
sucked away from you

116.92.text:
you'd be forgiven in
thinking that your blood

119.39.text:
and your body and your lungs
might kind of expand outwards

123.07.text: without the inward push of pressure,

125.64.text:
and they might more or less
expand to their breaking points

128.92.text: like marshmallows in a vacuum chamber.

131.17.text:
But what would really happen
to the human body in space,

134.40.text: aside from choking to death of course,

138.86.text:
Peter Quill was lucky
because space turns the body

141.44.text: into a bloated bag, not a bomb.

144.03.text: In the history of human space flight,

146.01.text:
no person has fully subjected
their bodies to the void,

149.33.text: but we do have a good idea

151.27.text:
of what would happen to
their bodies if they did

155.45.text:
like in 1965, when NASA
put a bunch of dogs

160.13.text: in a vacuum chamber and depressurized it,

162.51.text:
effectively throwing
them out of an airlock.

169.34.text: All animals exposed to the low pressure

171.56.text:
for longer than five seconds
tended to lose consciousness

174.99.text: and began to swell and collapse

185.11.text: they began to show marked expansion

194.40.text:
and gas expulsion from the
stomach and lower bowel,

211.34.text: And the water vapor and gas expansion

215.37.text:
that the animals quickly
became immobilized

218.09.text:
with the neck, body, and
extremities in extended positions

221.09.text:
similar in appearance to
an inflated goatskin bag.

237.47.text: It was also noticed in several animals

239.00.text: that after recompression to ground level,

241.49.text: the tongue was coated in ice.

246.49.text: After the test chamber was repressurized,

250.23.text:
some didn't depending on how
long they're exposed to vacuum,

255.86.text: After 24 hours, the dogs that did survive

258.52.text:
were back to normal, which
fits with another study,

261.40.text: also in 1965, also by NASA, on chimps.

265.78.text: But all the chimps in this study survived

268.44.text:
even after being exposed to
the vacuum of space for minutes

272.15.text: and showed no ill effects afterwards.

and you look like a gross

first the air in your tissues
and your blood would boil,

according to all the

437.07.text: So, how long could Star-Lord or you

442.38.text:
Well, based on all the

you could be conscious

448.94.text:
before you're passed out and

452.09.text: in which time you could be saved.

455.02.text: What I'm trying to say is that

456.88.text:
that scene in Guardians
